articles.headline: Growing Crisis in Its Backyard Snares Russia
articles.snippet: As Russia faces calls for an active response to Ukraine’s deepening political crisis, the question asked by many is whether President Vladimir V. Putin intended it that way.
articles.abstract: As Russia faces calls for an active response to Ukraine’s deepening political crisis, the question asked by many is whether President Vladimir V. Putin intended it that way.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Despite repeated vows not to interfere or intervene, President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia has now found itself more deeply ensnared than ever in Ukraine’s worsening political crisis, facing appeals to support the country’s ethnic Russians, provide haven for its deposed president and perhaps even undertake a military response. The question is whether he intended it that way.

articles.headline: A Dire Economic Forecast Based on New Assumptions
articles.snippet: This year’s economic forecasts from the Congressional Budget Office were worse than last year’s because the office stopped treating the recent slow years as outliers.
articles.abstract: This year’s economic forecasts from the Congressional Budget Office were worse than last year’s because the office stopped treating the recent slow years as outliers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The part of the past that you deem most relevant can be critical in determining your outlook for the future. And nowhere is that clearer than in the changing economic forecasts that come out of the Congressional Budget Office.

articles.headline: British Spies Said to Intercept Yahoo Webcam Images
articles.snippet: Accounts based on documents supplied by Edward J. Snowden say images — many sexually explicit — were collected from Yahoo users, even those not suspected of illegal activity.
articles.abstract: Accounts based on documents supplied by Edward J. Snowden say images — many sexually explicit — were collected from Yahoo users, even those not suspected of illegal activity.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A British intelligence agency collected video webcam images — many of them sexually explicit — from millions of Yahoo users, regardless of whether they were suspected of illegal activity, according to accounts of documents leaked by Edward J. Snowden.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Bakken Crude, Rolling Through Albany
articles.snippet: The instant growth in the oil-by-rail business is increasing the oil supply, but also raising alarms.
articles.abstract: The instant growth in the oil-by-rail business is increasing the oil supply, but also raising alarms.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALBANY — On a clear December morning two years ago, a 600-foot oceangoing oil tanker called the Stena Primorsk left the Port of Albany on its maiden voyage down the Hudson River laden with 279,000 barrels of crude oil. It quickly ran aground on a sandbar.

articles.headline: SeaWorld Questions Ethics of ‘Blackfish’ Investigator
articles.snippet: SeaWorld Entertainment has come under fire after a documentary criticized its practice of holding whales in captivity. Now, the company is firing back.
articles.abstract: SeaWorld Entertainment has come under fire after a documentary criticized its practice of holding whales in captivity. Now, the company is firing back.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — SeaWorld Entertainment, which has come under fire after the release of “Blackfish,” a critical documentary about whales in captivity, struck back Thursday at one of its government monitors for her supposed cozy relations with animal-rights activists and involvement in the film.

articles.headline: A Call to Give Consumers Their Credit Scores Free
articles.snippet: The federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau urged credit card companies to give customers free copies of their credit scores.
articles.abstract: The federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau urged credit card companies to give customers free copies of their credit scores.
articles.lead_paragraph: In its new role as consumer credit watchdog, the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Thursday urged credit card companies to give customers free copies of their credit scores — crucial pieces of financial information used to evaluate qualifications for mortgages, credit cards and even certain types of insurance and rental apartments.

articles.headline: Mortgage Servicer’s Ties Raise Regulatory Concern
articles.snippet: State and federal regulators are worried that Ocwen is mishandling some of the mortgages it services, citing examples of shoddy paperwork and faulty technology.
articles.abstract: State and federal regulators are worried that Ocwen is mishandling some of the mortgages it services, citing examples of shoddy paperwork and faulty technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mortgage servicers collect money from homeowners and distribute those payments to lenders. It’s a fairly boring business, but not to William C. Erbey.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: A Call to Arms on a Vermont Heroin Epidemic
articles.snippet: Rutland has begun an effort to attack a drug problem with social services, as well as with law enforcement.
articles.abstract: Rutland has begun an effort to attack a drug problem with social services, as well as with law enforcement.
articles.lead_paragraph: RUTLAND, Vt. — Block by block, this city in central Vermont has been fighting a heroin epidemic so entrenched that it has confounded all efforts to combat it.

articles.headline: Outrage Over Sexist Remarks Turns Into a Political Fund-Raising Tool
articles.snippet: With a record number of women in Congress and dozens more on the ballot, attacks on figures like Wendy Davis, Claire McCaskill and Hillary Rodham Clinton can instantly generate contributions.
articles.abstract: With a record number of women in Congress and dozens more on the ballot, attacks on figures like Wendy Davis, Claire McCaskill and Hillary Rodham Clinton can instantly generate contributions.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the past few months, Republicans have called Wendy Davis, a Democratic candidate for Texas governor, “Abortion Barbie,” likened Alison Lundergan Grimes, a Senate candidate from Kentucky, to an “empty dress,” criticized Hillary Rodham Clinton’s thighs, and referred to a pregnant woman as a “host.”

articles.headline: U.S. Militant, Hidden, Spurs Drone Debate
articles.snippet: The U.S. government is considering whether to again take the extraordinary step of authorizing the killing of an American citizen, now living in Pakistan.
articles.abstract: The U.S. government is considering whether to again take the extraordinary step of authorizing the killing of an American citizen, now living in Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He is known as Abdullah al-Shami, an Arabic name meaning Abdullah the Syrian. But his nom de guerre masks a reality: He was born in the United States, and the United States is now deciding whether to kill him.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: With Military Moves Seen in Ukraine, Obama Warns Russia
articles.snippet: The new Ukrainian government claimed that Russia was trying to provoke a military conflict by sending troops to Crimea, while President Obama warned Russia to respect Ukraine’s sovereignty.
articles.abstract: The new Ukrainian government claimed that Russia was trying to provoke a military conflict by sending troops to Crimea, while President Obama warned Russia to respect Ukraine’s sovereignty.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s fragile new government accused Russia of trying to provoke a military conflict by invading the Crimea region on Friday, while in Washington President Obama issued a stern warning to the Kremlin about respecting Ukraine’s sovereignty, in an effort to preclude a full-scale military escalation.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn, Mark Landler and Alison Smale

articles.headline: Erosion of Faith Was Death Knell for Mt. Gox
articles.snippet: Mt. Gox, once the largest Bitcoin exchange in the world, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday and said that it might have lost 750,000 of its customers’ coins in a hacking attack.
articles.abstract: Mt. Gox, once the largest Bitcoin exchange in the world, filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday and said that it might have lost 750,000 of its customers’ coins in a hacking attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Bitcoin exchange Mt. Gox was careening toward collapse in early February, its owner, Mark Karpeles, found that even some of his fellow virtual currency advocates were losing faith.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams Matthew Goldstein and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Currency of China Continues to Decline
articles.snippet: The renminbi lost 0.3 percent of its value against the dollar on Friday, and it has fallen 1.5 percent this year.
articles.abstract: The renminbi lost 0.3 percent of its value against the dollar on Friday, and it has fallen 1.5 percent this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The value of China’s currency, the renminbi, continued to slide against the United States dollar on Friday, rattling investors by falling to its lowest level in nearly a year before closing higher.

articles.headline: Citigroup Says Mexican Subsidiary Was Defrauded of as Much as $400 Million
articles.snippet: Citigroup said on Friday that it was revising its results for the fourth quarter and 2013 after it discovered a fraud involving its Mexican banking unit, Banamex, and an oil services company.
articles.abstract: Citigroup said on Friday that it was revising its results for the fourth quarter and 2013 after it discovered a fraud involving its Mexican banking unit, Banamex, and an oil services company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:56 p.m. | At the helm of Citigroup for just a year and a half, Michael L. Corbat has been trying to transform into a boring bank a global giant that has been plagued in the past by blowups and bailouts.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Elisabeth Malkin
